Other Vehicles
Add Vehicles No Vehicles
Add other vehicles
Stay Calm The crash site is a place to gather information, not assign or accept blame. Do not discuss who was at fault. Driver\'s Information Witness Name* Witness Phone* Witness Information Witness Statement* Add Witness No witness
If possible, take photos of the accident scene and damage to vehicles, physical evidence, or surrounding structures, but only if you can do so safely. Photograph the truck and/or trailer, making sure to get any damage, and identifying markings such as DOT numbers, logos, license tags and warnings such as HAZMAT information. If you are unable to take photographs, then make detailed notes or draw a diagram to record this information. Capture
Capture scene
Report the accident to your insurance company for towing/storing your vehicle, obtaining a rental replacement and arranging for repairs. Note where your vehicle will be taken to, if possible. Preserve your car, if you can; it can be important evidence. You should honestly report whether you feel injured, but all serious injuries are not immediately apparent during the rush of adrenaline following an accident, so you may want to withhold comments about whether you are injured until you have had the opportunity to be evaluated by a physician, if needed. When in doubt, if you are having any symptoms, it is better to seek medical attention immediately. As soon as possible following an accident, you or someone on your behalf needs to write the trucking company (DOT carrier) and request they not destroy any relevant documents, including the driver’s logs. Otherwise, key documents may be destroyed in the months following the accident. Truck Details
Insurance Provider DOT Number Vehicle Registration Truck Owner Details Driver\'s Employer Details Capture Proof Done
Take Incident Photo or Video
Add Images
Add Images / Videos
Incident Details Street Address Incident Date Incident Location Incident Time Vehicle Owner Details
Add Vehicle Detail Your Safety should be your first priority. Step 1 Move to a secure location, but do not leave the scene of the accident. Step 2 Do not stand near or between vehicles or near traffic. Step 3 Put out flares and/or reflectors if you have them. CALL 911 To summon the police so they can make an objective report. Step 4 Record Your Incident Report Number Step 5 Record police officer badge number, name and the police department where that officer works. Tips Do not discuss who was at fault The crash site is a place to gather information, not assign or accept blame. Step 6 Gather Photographic Evidence
Photographic Evidence No Photographic Evidence
Take photos of the accident scene and damage to vehicle,physical evidence or surrounding structures,but only if you can do it safely. Photographs of truck and/or trailer,making sure to get any damage, and identify markings such as DOT numbers,logos,license tags and warnings such as HAZMAT information. If you are unable to take photographs,then make detailed notes or draw a diagram to record this information. Step 7 Gather Witness Information Collect the names and phone numbers of witnesses. Ask them what they saw and write down their description. Step 8 Collect Information Collect information about the truck driver, including his name, address, phone number, operator license number, state of license, insurance provider, insurance policy number, the truck’s DOT number, vehicle license plate number and vehicle registration. Also collect name, contact information, and insurer information for the truck owner and the truck driver’s employer. Report Accident Insurance Company Report the accident to your insurance company for towing/storing your vehicle, obtaining a rental replacement and arranging for repairs. Note where your vehicle will be taken to, if possible. Preserve your car, if you can; it can be important evidence. Final Step You should honestly report whether you feel injured, but all serious injuries are not immediately apparent during the rush of adrenaline following an accident, so you may want to withhold comments about whether you are injured until you have had the opportunity to be evaluated by a physician, if needed. When in doubt, if you are having any symptoms, it is better to seek medical attention immediately. As soon as possible following an accident, you or someone on your behalf needs to write the trucking company (DOT carrier) and request they not destroy any relevant documents, including the driver’s logs. Otherwise, key documents may be destroyed in the months following the accident.
